Input: Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Dr. [Neurologist’s Name],

I am referring my patient, [Patient’s Name], for further neurologic evaluation and treatment. [Patient’s Name] is a [age]-year-old male/female whom I have been managing for an ascending weakness of the legs that has now progressed to the arms. Currently, [Patient’s Name] is barely able to move arms against gravity and has developed difficulty with respiration and bulbar compromise. This presentation, coupled with the clinical suspicion, led us to diagnose him/her with G61.0 - Guillain-Barre syndrome. He/She is currently on IVIG.

In light of the above, I would appreciate it if you could kindly evaluate [Patient’s Name]’s case and help us manage the condition. Thank you for considering this request. Kindly let us know of your availability, and we will schedule an appointment.

Best regards,

Input: Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer a patient to you for further assessment and management. The patient, Mrs. Y, presented with bilateral lower limb weakness and left upper arm weakness. She has a long history of back pain and had a small cervical syrinx found when she presented in 2011 following a fall down stairs. She underwent several years of rehabilitation and has been mobilising independently for one year now.

She presented on 19-12-15 with weakness in her left upper limb and complete flaccidity in her bilateral lower limbs. Initially, she reported urinary incontinence, but this has since resolved. On clinical examination, there was normal tone in all limbs apart from the left hand, which was held in flexion and resistant to movement, suggestive of longstanding spasticity (patient reports as new). Her power was 5-5 in her right arm and 1-5 power in her left arm. Bilateral lower limbs were 0-5 - completely flaccid. Reflexes were normal throughout. We feel that, given her unclear diagnosis from neurology and unclear history, this may have an underlying psychological aspect to her condition.

We believe that further evaluation and management are necessary and would welcome your clarification and assistance in this matter. She has not had an MRI on this admission, as it is felt that this is most likely functional and a repeat MRI would feed into this.

Thank you for considering this request.

Sincerely,

Dear Consultant,

I am writing to request a referral to your First Fit Clinic for a 43-year-old patient who has been diagnosed with R56.9 - Unspecified convulsions. The patient was seen in ED on the 15-9-19 after experiencing an episode in which she fell to the floor, eyes rolled back, and had jerking of all 4 limbs for two minutes. Witnesses say there was no tongue biting or incontinence. The patient had been sitting at a table at 4 am and had two rum and cokes before the event occurred. The patient has stated that there has been recent stress due to being evicted and her son having ADHD. The patient does not drive. We have requested an OP EEG and MRI for the patient.

We would be grateful if you could see the patient in Outpatients and provide your expert care and attention.

Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear [Doctor’s Name],

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient’s Name], who presented yesterday with a severe stabbing headache over the left temple. His symptom lasted for over 30 minutes, and he reported that he was unable to use his mobile phone for texting. He had a nap and woke up feeling strange, with left leg weakness and pins and needles in the left hand. His partner reported that he had left facial droop and that he was speaking slowly. He did not experience photophobia.

He has no history of migraines, and his headache disappeared by the time he woke up today, but he had a throbbing frontal headache that was not severe. I suspect a hemiplegic migraine or a possible TIA, but the presentation is atypical. I would greatly appreciate your assessment and advice on this matter.

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,

I am writing to refer my patient, a 35-year-old female, who has been diagnosed with G61.0 - Guillain-Barre syndrome. Dear Dr. Neurologist,

I am writing to request a neurology assessment for my 56-year-old patient who has been presenting with unexplained convulsions. The patient recently visited the TIA clinic after experiencing left-sided headaches, discrete episodes of dysphasia (receptive), and an abnormal movement of the right wrist. She was also vomiting and had resolved symptoms during the neurological examination.

We studied the patient's history in detail and consulted with neoradiologists and neurosurgical registrars from Southampton, who identified possible appearance of multiple sclerosis plaques or vascular abnormalities resulting from a background of small vessel disease. Anti-convulsants have been suggested as a treatment.

We are hoping to seek your guidance in assessing the patient's symptoms in light of the imaging results and determine if the patient requires anticonvulsant medication. Thank you for your kind assistance in this matter.

Best regards,

Dear Dr. [name],

I am writing to refer my patient [patient name] to you for further management of his epilepsy. He has been diagnosed with transient epileptic amnesia and has a history of seizures. His most recent admission was in August 2016, where he presented with confusion and drowsiness following a seizure. At that time, Dr. [name] suggested adding clobazem at night on top of lamotrigine 100mg BD.

Currently, he has been found unresponsive and drowsy by his friend and has been admitted to our hospital. On admission, he had a fluctuating GCS and a temperature with some suprapubic tenderness. However, his inflammatory markers were normal, and he is currently stable with GCS 15-15.

Given his complex condition, I believe that your expertise in managing epilepsy will be invaluable in helping him achieve better control of his seizures. I would appreciate it if you could review his case and provide your opinion on his further management.

Thank you for considering this referral. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further information.

Kind regards,

Dear [Referring physician],

I am writing to refer a patient to your care who has been diagnosed with R55-Syncope and collapse. The patient, [Patient Name], was admitted to our facility after a fall with loss of consciousness. It is thought likely that the incident was secondary to postural hypotension, as the patient reports experiencing two falls per day. While admitted, we found that the patient's inflammatory markers were raised but ultimately settled after being treated for aspiration pneumonia.

The patient usually lives fairly independently at home and does not require a package of care. However, they do have a past medical history of AF and CVA 2017 involving two tiny sites of hemorrhage in the right cerebellar hemisphere and corpus callosum, as well as thalassemia trait and portal hypertension.

Prior to admission, the patient experienced poor oral intake, leading to associated weight loss on the background of a low BMI. We reviewed the patient's condition with our speech and language therapy team and found that they have severe oropharyngeal dysphagia. I am referring this 88-year-old lady to you for further assessment and management of her symptoms. She was admitted to our hospital due to unusual epileptic episodes that sometimes lead to suicidal attempts. The episodes involve agitation, distress, and aggression, and her speech becomes rambling and nonsensical. Her episodes last for about two hours and require restraint while they are occurring. She experiences "blinding headaches" and drowsiness after the episodes end. She also recently developed delusions that her family and other people are attempting to kill her. These episodes have been coming on with increasing frequency.

Further, this unfortunate patient recently developed some strange episodes that resemble migraines, such as photophobia and visual changes with zig-zag lines. These episodes have been coming on with increased frequency and were happening several times per day in the lead-up to her admission. She has no history of mental health problems, and there is no family history of psychiatric illness or dementia.

Our psychiatry liaison believes that she may be suffering from a neurological condition rather than a psychiatric one. The brief events that she experienced earlier could be migrainous aetiology, or it could have been epileptiform. I believe that this requires further investigation, and thus, I am referring her to you.

Thank you for considering this referral.

Sincerely,

Upon admission, he felt well and exhibited no focal neurology.

Dr. Cossburn has advised starting lamotrigine 25mg OD, gradually increasing every two weeks to 75mg BD. He has also suggested arranging an outpatient MRI and following up Mr. XXXX in the first fit clinic. Thank you for your care of Mr. XXXX.

Input: Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Dr. [Referring Doctor's Name],

I am writing to refer a patient, [Patient's Name], who was recently admitted to our hospital with symptoms of disorientation, unspecified. The patient was admitted to our hospital on 1-9-15 following a tonic-clonic seizure. The seizure was thought to be secondary to a low magnesium after starting Omeprazole 40mg QDS. The patient did not remember the events and had no prodromal symptoms. A CT Brain was performed which showed no change in the size of the left MCA aneurysm, apart from a slight increase in calcification. Magnesium was replaced IV, and omeprazole changed to ranitidine. The patient returned back to normal and was therefore discharged.

Since being discharged, the patient's family has noticed him becoming increasingly confused with reports of visual hallucinations. He became more restless and aggressive so was brought to the ED. On admission, he reported having visual hallucinations since discharge associated with a headache. There was no history of fever. He had no speech-visual disturbance, no focal weakness in extremities. Throughout the day he became increasingly confused and agitated. He absconded from the hospital, very unsteady, unsafe on feet, aggressive, and difficult to manage. The patient was reviewed by the psychiatric team who found him to be floridly psychotic, disorientated in time, place, and person, as well as paranoid (believing staff wanted to harm him). He also appeared to be experiencing auditory and visual hallucinations. He was given IM haloperidol initially, but this had little effect so at MET Call was put out. On arrival, the patient was needing a lot of encouragement and restraint to keep him in his room, and was grabbing and his head and rolling around. He was therefore given IV haloperidol and his friend was then able to calm him somewhat. He was then brought up to ITU where he was Intubated and Ventilated to allow for a repeat CT Brain and Lumbar puncture. We would appreciate your advice on further investigations and management of this patient.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer my patient with a diagnosis of I63.9 - Cerebral infarction, unspecified for further management under your care.

Non-fluent aphasia was observed on admission, with no sensory, motor, or visual symptoms elicited.

Imaging of the patient showed a hyperintense lesion at the anterior corpus callosum, crossing the midline in addition to the left frontal lesion. On the last neuro-rad MDT discussion, LP was suggested (of note LP was attempted prior to this several times on the ward, though unsuccessful, and the patient was reluctant for re-attempts).

Please see the patient before Tuesday 27 March.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dear [Neurologist's Name],

I am writing to request your opinion on a patient of mine who was admitted to our hospital with left leg pain and weakness, numbness in the left arm, and loss of sight in her left eye. Furthermore, she developed weakness and numbness in her left arm but was still able to move it. Today, upon examination, we noted patchy decreased sensation in the left side of her face, left hand, and minimal decreased sensation in her left forearm. Her left leg had decreased power of 2-5, and she experienced shooting pain upon passive left ankle flexion and leg raise. Her eye movements and CN examination were normal. After reassurance that a structural cause had been excluded, we started her on gabapentin for the nerve-type pain and asked our physio team to review her. We are unsure if this maybe a functional weakness or if any further investigation or treatment is needed, which is why we are seeking your expertise in this matter. 

Could you please review the patient and provide recommendations on how to proceed appropriately? 

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dear Specialist,

Dear Specialist,
I am writing to refer my patient who has been recently diagnosed with R41.0 - Disorientation, unspecified.

He did not remember the events and had no prodromal symptoms. There was no history of previous seizure. CT Brain was performed which showed no change in the size of the left MCA aneurysm. Since he was discharged his family noticed him to become increasingly confused with reports of visual hallucinations. He became more restless and aggressive and was brought to ED. On admission, he reported having visual hallucinations since discharge associated with a headache. There was no history of fever. Throughout the day he became increasingly confused and agitated. He absconded from the hospital and was brought back by a passing paramedic. He was reviewed by the psychiatric team who found him to be floridly psychotic with disorientation and paranoid delusions. He clearly lacked capacity and became increasingly aggressive. He was given IM haloperidol 2.5mg initially which had little effect, so a MET Call was put out. On arrival, he was needing a lot of encouragement and restraint to keep him in his room, and was grabbing his head and rolling around. He was therefore given 5mg IV of haloperidol and his friend was then able to calm him somewhat. He was then brought up to ITU where he was Intubated and Ventilated to allow for a repeat CT Brain and Lumbar puncture. Please could you advise on the further investigations and management of this patient.
Thank you for your help.
